text: [Music]
Can I can I say how delighted I am to be
away from the the calm of uh Westminster
and White?
This is Kim, the 9-year-old Vietnam
girl.
her back
uh ruined by napalam
and she awakened the conscience of a
nation in America to begin to end the
Vietnam war.
This is Beerham
who was the Ethiopian girl who uh
launched live aid in the 1980s
15 minutes away from death when she was
rescued. And that picture of her being
rescued is one that went round the
world.
This is Tanaman Square. A man before a
tank became a picture that became a
symbol for the whole world of
resistance.
This next
is the Sudin girl a few moments from
from death. A vulture hovering in the
background. A picture that went round
the world and shocked people into action
on poverty.
And this is Nidita, the Iranian girl who
was shot while at a demonstration with
her father in Iran only a few weeks ago.
And she is now the focus,
rightly so, of the YouTube generation.
And what do all these pictures and
events have in common?
What they have in common is what we see
unlocks what we cannot see.
What we see unlocks the invisible ties
and bonds of sympathy that bring us
together
to become a human community.
What these pictures demonstrate is that
we do feel the pain of others however
distantly. What I think these pictures
demonstrate is we do believe in
something bigger than ourselves. What
these pictures demonstrate is that there
is a moral sense across all religions,
across all faiths, across all
continents. A moral sense that not only
do we share the pain of others and
believe in something bigger than
ourselves, but we have a duty to act
when we see things that are wrong that
need writed, see injuries that need to
be corrected, see problems that need to
be rectified.
There's a story about uh Olaf Palmy the
Swedish prime minister going to see
Ronald Reagan in America in the 1980s
and before he arrived Ronald Reagan said
and he was the Swedish social democratic
prime minister isn't this man a
communist
and the reply was no Mr. president. He's
an anti-communist. And Ronald Reagan
said, "I don't care what kind of
communist he is."
And
and Ronald Reagan asked Olaf Palmy, the
social democratic prime minister of
Sweden, "Well, what what do you believe
in? Do you want to abolish the rich?"
And he said, "No, I want to abolish the
poor. Our responsibility is to let
everyone have the chance to realize the
potential to the full." And I believe
that there is a moral sense and a global
ethic that commands attention from
people of every religion and every faith
and people of no faith. But I think
what's new is that we now have the
capacity to communicate instantaneously
across frontiers right across the world.
But we now have the capacity to find
common ground with people who we will
never meet but who we can meet through
the internet uh and through all the
modern means of communication that we
now have the capacity to organize and
take collective action together to deal
with a problem or an injustice that we
want to deal with. And I believe that
this makes this a unique age in human
history. And it is the start of what I
will call the creation of a truly global
society. Go back 200 years when the
slave trade was under pressure from
William Wilberforce and all the
protesters.
They protested across Britain. They won
public opinion over a long period of
time. But it took 24 years for the
campaign to be successful. What could
they have done with the pictures that
they could have shown if they were able
to use the modern means of communication
to win people's hearts and minds? Or if
you take Eglantine Jeb, the woman who
created save the children 90 years ago,
she was so appalled by what was
happening in Austria as a result of the
first world war and what was happening
to children who were part of the
defeated uh families of Austria. that in
Britain she wanted to take action, but
she had to go house to house, leaflet to
leaflet to get people to attend a rally
in the Royal Albert Hall that eventually
gave birth to Save the Children, an
international organization that's now
fully recognized as one of the great
institutions in in our land and in the
world. But what more could she have done
if she had the modern means of
communications available to her to
create a sense that the injustice that
people saw had to be acted upon
immediately. Now look at what's happened
in the last 10 years in Philippines in
2001. President Estrada a million people
texted each other about the corruption
of that regime eventually brought him
down and it was of course called the
coup detext.
Then you had in Zimbabwe the first
election under Robert Mugabi a year ago
because people were able to take mobile
phone photographs of what was happening
at the polling stations. It was
impossible for that premier to fix that
election in the way that he wanted to
do. Or take Burma and the monks that
were blogging out a country that nobody
knew anything about what was happening
until these blogs told the world that
there was a pre a repression that was
meaning that lives were being lost and
people were being persecuted and
Ansunuki who is one of the great uh
prisoners of conscience of the world uh
had uh to be listened to and then take
Iran itself and what people are doing
today
following what happened to Nida people
who are preventing the security services
of Iran, finding those people who are
blogging out of Iran by everybody who is
blogging changing their address to toran
Iran and making it difficult for the
security services. Now take therefore
what modern technology is capable of to
the power of our moral sense allied to
the power of modern communications and
our ability to organize internationally.
That in my view gives us the first
opportunity as a community to
fundamentally change the world. Foreign
policy can never be the same again. It
cannot be run by elites. It's got to be
run by listening to the public opinions
uh of peoples who are blogging, who are
communicating with each other around the
world. Now 200 years ago, the problem we
had to solve was slavery.
150 years ago, I suppose the main
problem in a country like ours was how
young people, children had the right to
education. 100 years ago, in most uh
countries in in Europe, the pressure was
for the right to vote. 50 years ago, the
pressure was for the right to social
security and welfare. In the last 50 60
years, we've seen fascism,
anti-semitism, racism, uh apartheid, uh
discrimination on the basis of sex and
gender and sexuality. All these have
come under pressure because of the
campaigns that have been run by people
to change the world. I was with Nelson
Mandela a year ago when he was in
London. And I was at a concert that he
was attending uh to mark uh his birthday
and for the uh creation of new resources
for his foundation. And I was sitting
next to Nelson Mandela, very privileged
to do so when Amy Winehouse came on to
the stage. And Nelson Mandela was quite
uh surprised at the appearance of this
singer. And I was explaining to him,
took took a bit of time who she was and
uh what she was up to. And Amy Wer has
said, "Nelson Mandela and I have got a
lot in common." He said, "My husband too
has spent a long time in prison."
Anyway, Nelson Mandela then went down to
the stage and he summarized uh the
challenge for us all. He said in his
lifetime he had climbed a great
mountain. The mountain of challenging
and then defeating racial oppression and
defeating apartheid. But he said there
was a greater challenge still ahead. The
challenge of poverty, of climate change,
global challenges that needed global
solutions and needed the creation of a
truly global society. Now we are the
first generation which is in a position
uh to do this. Combine the power of a
global ethic with the power of our
ability to communicate and organize
globally with the challenges that we now
face most of which are global in their
nature. Climate change cannot be solved
in one country but has got to be solved
by the world working together. A
financial crisis just as we've seen
could not be solved by America alone or
Europe alone. It needed the world to
work together. Take the problems of
security and terrorism and equally the
problem of human rights and development.
They cannot be solved by Africa alone.
They cannot be solved by America or
Europe alone. We cannot solve these
problems unless we work together. So the
great project of our generation, it
seems to me, is to build for the first
time out of a global ethic and our
global ability to communicate and
organize together a truly global society
built on that ethic, but with
institutions that can serve that global
society and make for a different future.
And we have now and are the first
generation with the power to do this.
Take climate change. Is it not
absolutely scandalous that we have a
situation where we know that there is a
climate change problem where we know
also that that will mean that we will
have to give more resources to the
poorest countries to deal with that?
When we want to create a global carbon
market but there is no global
institution that people have been agreed
been able to agree upon to deal with
this problem. And one of the things
that's got to come out of Copenhagen in
the next few months is an agreement that
there will be a global environmental
institution that is able to deal with
the problems of persuading the whole of
the world to move along a climate change
agenda. And one of the
[Music]
and one of the reasons and one of the
reasons why an institution is not in
itself enough is that we have got to
persuade people around the world to
change the behavior as well. So you need
that global ethic of fairness and
responsibility across the generations.
Take the financial crisis. If people in
poorer countries can be hit by a crisis
that starts in New York or starts in the
subprime market of the United States of
America, if people can find that that
subprime product has been transferred
across nations many many times until it
ends up in banks in Iceland or the rest
of Britain and people's ordinary savings
are affected by it. Then you cannot rely
on a system of national supervision. You
need in the long run for stability, for
economic growth, for jobs as well as for
financial stability, global economic
institutions that make sure that growth
to be sustained has to be shared and are
built on the principle that the
prosperity of this world is indivisible.
So another challenge for our generation
is to create global institutions that
reflect our ideas of fairness and
responsibility, not the ideas that were
at the basis of the last stage of
financial development over these recent
years. and then take development and
take the partnership we need between our
countries uh and the rest of the world,
the poorest part of the world. We do not
have the basis of a proper partnership
for the future. And yet out of people's
desire for a global ethic and a global
society that can be done. I've just been
talking to the president of Sierra Leon.
This is a country six and a half million
people, but it has only 80 doctors. It
is 200 nurses. It is 120 midwives. You
cannot begin to build a health care
system for six million people with such
limited resources. Or take the girl I
met when I was in Tanzania, a girl
called Miriam.
She was 11 years old. Her parents had
both died from AIDS. Her mother and then
her father. She was an AIDS orphan being
handed across different uh extended
families to be to be cared for. She
herself was suffering from HIV. She was
suffering from tuberculosis. I met her
in a field. She was ragged. She had no
shoes. When you looked in her eyes, any
girl at the age of 11 is looking forward
to the future.
But there was an unreachable sadness in
that girl's eyes. And if I could have
translated that to the rest of the world
for that moment, I believe that all the
work that is done for the global HIV
AIDS fund would be rewarded by people
being prepared to make donations. But we
must then build a proper relationship
between the richest and the poorest
countries based on our desire that they
are able to fend for themselves with the
investment that is necessary in their
agriculture so that Africa is not a net
importer of food but Africa is an
exporter of food and take the problems
of human rights and the problems of
security in so many countries around the
world. Burma is in change. Zimbabwe is a
human tragedy. Sudan, thousands of
people have died unnecessarily for wars
that we could prevent.
In the Rwanda Children's Museum,
there is a photograph of a 10-year-old
boy.
And the Children's Museum is
commemorating the lives that were lost
in the Rwanda genocide when a million
people died. And there is a photograph
of a boy called David. And beside that
photograph there is the information
about his life and it said David age 10.
David ambition to be a doctor. Favorite
sport football. What he enjoyed most.
Making people laugh.
How did he died? Tortured to death.
Last words said to his mother who was
also tortured death to death. don't
worry, the United Nations are coming.
And we never did. And that young boy
believed our promises that we would help
people in difficulty in Rwanda. And we
never did. So we have got to create in
this world also institutions for
peacekeeping and humanitarian aid, but
also for reconstruction and security for
some of the conflictridden states of the
world. So my argument today is basically
this. We have the means by which we can
create a truly global society. The
institutions of these global this global
society can be created by our endeavors.
That global ethic can infuse the
fairness and responsibility that is
necessary for these institutions to
work. But we should not lose the chance
in this uh generation in this decade in
particular with President Obama and
America with other people working with
us around the world uh to create global
institutions for the environment and for
finance and for security and for
development that make sense of our
responsibility to other people's our
desire to bind the world together and
the need to tackle problems that
everybody knows exist. It's said in uh
ancient uh Rome that when Cicero spoke
to his audiences, people used to turn to
each other and say about Cicero, great
great speech. But it's said that in
ancient Greece when Deosineses spoke to
his audiences, people turned to each
other and didn't say great speech. They
said let's march. We should be marching
towards a global society. Thank you.
Heat.
